head.title: Council on State Mandates Likely to Start Work Soon

hedline.hl1: Council on State Mandates Likely to Start Work Soon

block.p: There'll be no more passing the buck from the Legislature down to county and local governments -- and thereby forcing local property taxes up -- under a new monitoring group that the State Senate is expected to establish tomorrow.

In November, voters agreed nearly 2 to 1 that they no longer wanted the Legislature to make decisions that cost local taxpayers money. They approved a constitutional amendment known as "state mandate, state pay."

There'll be no more passing the buck from the Legislature down to county and local governments -- and thereby forcing local property taxes up -- under a new monitoring group that the State Senate is expected to establish tomorrow.

In November, voters agreed nearly 2 to 1 that they no longer wanted the Legislature to make decisions that cost local taxpayers money. They approved a constitutional amendment known as "state mandate, state pay."

The new Council on Local Mandates, consisting of members appointed by the Governor, the Senate President, the Assembly Speaker and the Chief Justice, is to rule on complaints brought by local bodies when they think the Legislature is trying to pass along costs.

Senate President Donald T. DiFrancesco, Republican of Scotch Plains, says implementing the amendment is a priority. After the legislation to create the council was released by two Senate committees last week, he said he expected the council to be up and running in a few weeks.
